column2: CHAPTER VIII
column3: CHAPTER eight

column2: A STRING OF GOLD BEADS
column3: A STRING OF GOLD BEADS

column2: A moment later Bates entered with a fresh supply of wood.
column3: A moment later Bates entered with a fresh supply of wood.

column2: I watched him narrowly for some sign of perturbation, but he was not to be caught off guard.
column3: I watched him narrowly for some sign of perturbation, but he was not to be caught off guard.

column2: Possibly he had not heard the shots in the wood; at any rate, he tended the fire with his usual gravity, and after brushing the hearth paused respectfully.
column3: Possibly he had not heard the shots in the wood; at any rate, he tended the fire with his usual gravity, and after brushing the hearth paused respectfully.

column2: “Is there anything further, sir?”
column3: Is there anything further, sir?

column2: “I believe not, Bates.
column3:
I believe not, Bates.	true	35.75	37.06	27.287552
4595_45204_000004_000001	Oh! here’s a hammer I picked up out in the grounds a bit ago.	Oh! here's a hammer I picked up out in the grounds a bit ago.	true	37.1	40.63	24.509344
4595_45204_000004_000002	I wish you’d see if it belongs to the house.”	I wish you'd see if it belongs to the house.

column2: He examined the implement with care and shook his head.
column3: He examined the implement with care and shook his head.

column2: “It doesn’t belong here, I think, sir.
column3:
It doesn't belong here, I think, sir.	true	47.21	49.93	23.172726
4595_45204_000006_000001	But we sometimes find tools left by the carpenters that worked on the house.	But we sometimes find tools left by the carpenters that worked on the house.	true	49.94	55	26.133545
4595_45204_000006_000002	Shall I put this in the tool-chest, sir?”	Shall I put this in the tool chest, sir?

column2: “Never mind.
column3:
Never mind.	true	58.53	59.41	20.97704
4595_45204_000007_000001	I need such a thing now and then and I’ll keep it handy.”	I need such a thing now and then and I'll keep it handy.

column2: “Very good, Mr. Glenarm.
column3:
Very good, mr Glenarm.	true	63.74	65.74	29.524843
4595_45204_000008_000001	It’s a bit sharper to-night, but we’re likely to have sudden changes at this season.”	It's a bit sharper to night, but we're likely to have sudden changes at this season.

column2: “I dare say.”
column3: I dare say.

column2: We were not getting anywhere; the fellow was certainly an incomparable actor.
column3: We were not getting anywhere; the fellow was certainly an incomparable actor.

column2: “You must find it pretty lonely here, Bates.
column3:
You must find it pretty lonely here, Bates.	true	78.29	80.68	24.211071
4595_45204_000011_000001	Don’t hesitate to go to the village when you like.”	Don't hesitate to go to the village when you like.

column2: “I thank you, Mr. Glenarm; but I am not much for idling.
column3:
I thank you, mr Glenarm; but I am not much for idling.	false	84.41	88.09	26.106329
4595_45204_000012_000001	I keep a few books by me for the evenings.	I keep a few books by me for the evenings.	true	88.25	91.09	27.99764
4595_45204_000012_000002	Annandale is not what you would exactly call a diverting village.”	Annandale is not what you would exactly call a diverting village.

column2: “I fancy not.
column3:
I fancy not.	true	96.08	97.36	21.435442
4595_45204_000013_000001	But the caretaker over at the summer resort has even a lonelier time, I suppose.	But the caretaker over at the summer resort has even a lonelier time, I suppose.	true	97.49	101.86	22
4595_45204_000013_000002	That’s what I’d call a pretty cheerless job,—watching summer cottages in the winter.”	That's what I'd call a pretty cheerless job,—watching summer cottages in the winter.

column2: “That’s Morgan, sir.
column3:
That's Morgan, sir.	true	107.21	108.85	31.62862
4595_45204_000014_000001	I meet him occasionally when I go to the village; a very worthy person, I should call him, on slight acquaintance.”	I meet him occasionally when I go to the village; a very worthy person, I should call him, on slight acquaintance.

column2: “No doubt of it, Bates.
column3:
No doubt of it, Bates.	true	117.23	118.63	24.151258
4595_45204_000015_000001	Any time through the winter you want to have him in for a social glass, it’s all right with me.”	Any time through the winter you want to have him in for a social glass, it's all right with me.

column2: He met my gaze without flinching, and lighted me to the stair with our established ceremony.
column3: He met my gaze without flinching, and lighted me to the stair with our established ceremony.

column2: I voted him an interesting knave and really admired the cool way in which he carried off difficult situations.
column3: I voted him an interesting knave and really admired the cool way in which he carried off difficult situations.

column2: I had no intention of being killed, and now that I had due warning of danger, I resolved to protect myself from foes without and within.
column3: I had no intention of being killed, and now that I had due warning of danger, I resolved to protect myself from foes without and within.

column2: Both Bates and Morgan, the caretaker, were liars of high attainment.
column3: Both Bates and Morgan, the caretaker, were liars of high attainment.

column2: Morgan was, moreover, a cheerful scoundrel, and experience taught me long ago that a knave with humor is doubly dangerous.
column3: Morgan was, moreover, a cheerful scoundrel, and experience taught me long ago that a knave with humor is doubly dangerous.

column2: Before going to bed I wrote a long letter to Larry Donovan, giving him a full account of my arrival at Glenarm House.
column3: Before going to bed I wrote a long letter to Larry Donovan, giving him a full account of my arrival at Glenarm House.

column2: The thought of Larry always cheered me, and as the pages slipped from my pen I could feel his sympathy and hear him chuckling over the lively beginning of my year at Glenarm.
column3: The thought of Larry always cheered me, and as the pages slipped from my pen I could feel his sympathy and hear him chuckling over the lively beginning of my year at Glenarm.

column2: The idea of being fired upon by an unseen foe would, I knew, give Larry a real lift of the spirit.
column3: The idea of being fired upon by an unseen foe would, I knew, give Larry a real lift of the spirit.

column2: The next morning I walked into the village, mailed my letter, visited the railway station with true rustic instinct and watched the cutting out of a freight car for Annandale with a pleasure I had not before taken in that proceeding.
column3: The next morning I walked into the village, mailed my letter, visited the railway station with true rustic instinct and watched the cutting out of a freight car for Annandale with a pleasure I had not before taken in that proceeding.

column2: The villagers stared at me blankly as on my first visit.
column3: The villagers stared at me blankly as on my first visit.

column2: A group of idle laborers stopped talking to watch me; and when I was a few yards past them they laughed at a remark by one of the number which I could not overhear.
column3: A group of idle laborers stopped talking to watch me; and when I was a few yards past them they laughed at a remark by one of the number which I could not overhear.

column2: But I am not a particularly sensitive person; I did not care what my Hoosier neighbors said of me; all I asked was that they should refrain from shooting at the back of my head through the windows of my own house.
column3: But I am not a particularly sensitive person; I did not care what my Hoosier neighbors said of me; all I asked was that they should refrain from shooting at the back of my head through the windows of my own house.

column2: On this day I really began to work.
column3: On this day I really began to work.

column2: I mapped out a course of reading, set up a draftsman’s table I found put away in a closet, and convinced myself that I was beginning a year of devotion to architecture.
column3: I mapped out a course of reading, set up a draftsman's table I found put away in a closet, and convinced myself that I was beginning a year of devotion to architecture.

column2: Such was, I felt, the only honest course.
column3: Such was, I felt, the only honest course.

column2: I should work every day from eight until one, and my leisure I should give to recreation and a search for the motives that lay behind the crafts and assaults of my enemies.
column3: I should work every day from eight until one, and my leisure I should give to recreation and a search for the motives that lay behind the crafts and assaults of my enemies.

column2: When I plunged into the wood in the middle of the afternoon it was with the definite purpose of returning to the upper end of the lake for an interview with Morgan, who had, so Bates informed me, a small house back of the cottages.
column3: When I plunged into the wood in the middle of the afternoon it was with the definite purpose of returning to the upper end of the lake for an interview with Morgan, who had, so Bates informed me, a small house back of the cottages.

column2: I took the canoe I had chosen for my own use from the boat-house and paddled up the lake.
column3: I took the canoe I had chosen for my own use from the boat house and paddled up the lake.

column2: The air was still warm, but the wind that blew out of the south tasted of rain.
column3: The air was still warm, but the wind that blew out of the south tasted of rain.

column2: I scanned the water and the borders of the lake for signs of life,—more particularly, I may as well admit, for a certain maroon-colored canoe and a girl in a red tam-o’-shanter, but lake and summer cottages were mine alone.
column3: I scanned the water and the borders of the lake for signs of life,—more particularly, I may as well admit, for a certain maroon colored canoe and a girl in a red tam o'-shanter, but lake and summer cottages were mine alone.

column2: I landed and began at once my search for Morgan.
column3: I landed and began at once my search for Morgan.

column2: There were many paths through the woods back of the cottages, and I followed several futilely before I at last found a small house snugly bid away in a thicket of young maples.
column3: There were many paths through the woods back of the cottages, and I followed several futilely before I at last found a small house snugly bid away in a thicket of young maples.

column2: The man I was looking for came to the door quickly in response to my knock.
column3: The man I was looking for came to the door quickly in response to my knock.

column2: “Good afternoon, Morgan.”
column3: Good afternoon, Morgan.

column2: “Good afternoon, Mr. Glenarm,” he said, taking the pipe from his mouth the better to grin at me.
column3: Good afternoon, mr Glenarm, he said, taking the pipe from his mouth the better to grin at me.

column2: He showed no sign of surprise, and I was nettled by his cool reception.
column3: He showed no sign of surprise, and I was nettled by his cool reception.

column2: There was, perhaps, a certain element of recklessness in my visit to the house of a man who had shown so singular an interest in my affairs, and his cool greeting vexed me.
column3: There was, perhaps, a certain element of recklessness in my visit to the house of a man who had shown so singular an interest in my affairs, and his cool greeting vexed me.

column2: “Morgan—”
column3: Morgan—

column2: I began.
column3: I began.

column2: “Won’t you come in and rest yourself, Mr. Glenarm?” he interrupted.
column3: Won't you come in and rest yourself, mr Glenarm? he interrupted.

column2: “I reckon you’re tired from your trip over—”
column3: I reckon you're tired from your trip over—

column2: “Thank you, no,” I snapped.
column3: Thank you, no, I snapped.

column2: “Suit yourself, Mr. Glenarm.”
column3: Suit yourself, mr Glenarm.

column2: He seemed to like my name and gave it a disagreeable drawling emphasis.
column3: He seemed to like my name and gave it a disagreeable drawling emphasis.

column2: “Morgan, you are an infernal blackguard.
column3:
Morgan, you are an infernal blackguard.	true	330.62	333.765	24.760721
4595_45204_000029_000001	You have tried twice to kill me—”	You have tried twice to kill me—

column2: “We’ll call it that, if you like,”—and he grinned. “But you’d better cut off one for this.”
column3: We'll call it that, if you like,—and he grinned. "But you'd better cut off one for this."

column2: He lifted the gray fedora hat from his head, and poked his finger through a hole in the top.
column3: He lifted the gray fedora hat from his head, and poked his finger through a hole in the top.

column2: “You’re a pretty fair shot, Mr. Glenarm.
column3:
You're a pretty fair shot, mr Glenarm.	true	347.54	349.84	23.807554
4595_45204_000032_000001	The fact about me is,”—and he winked,—”the honest truth is, I’m all out of practice.	The fact about me is,—and he winked,—"the honest truth is, I'm all out of practice.

column2: Why, sir, when I saw you paddling out on the lake this afternoon I sighted you from the casino half a dozen times with my gun, but I was afraid to risk it.”
column3: Why, sir, when I saw you paddling out on the lake this afternoon I sighted you from the casino half a dozen times with my gun, but I was afraid to risk it."

column2: He seemed to be shaken with inner mirth.
column3: He seemed to be shaken with inner mirth.

column2: “If I’d missed, I wasn’t sure you’d be scared to death!”
column3: If I'd missed, I wasn't sure you'd be scared to death!

column2: For a novel diversion I heartily recommend a meeting with the assassin who has, only a few days or hours before, tried to murder you.
column3: For a novel diversion I heartily recommend a meeting with the assassin who has, only a few days or hours before, tried to murder you.

column2: I know of nothing in the way of social adventure that is quite equal to it.
column3: I know of nothing in the way of social adventure that is quite equal to it.

column2: Morgan was a fellow of intelligence and, whatever lay back of his designs against me, he was clearly a foe to reckon with.
column3: Morgan was a fellow of intelligence and, whatever lay back of his designs against me, he was clearly a foe to reckon with.

column2: He stood in the doorway calmly awaiting my next move.
column3: He stood in the doorway calmly awaiting my next move.

column2: I struck a match on my box and lighted a cigarette.
column3: I struck a match on my box and lighted a cigarette.

column2: “Morgan, I hope you understand that I am not responsible for any injury my grandfather may have inflicted on you.
column3:
Morgan, I hope you understand that I am not responsible for any injury my grandfather may have inflicted on you.	false	396.98	403.24	24.114832
4595_45204_000034_000001	I hadn’t seen him for several years before he died.	I hadn't seen him for several years before he died.	true	403.55	405.99	23.81656
4595_45204_000034_000002	I was never at Glenarm before in my life, so it’s a little rough for you to visit your displeasure on me.”	I was never at Glenarm before in my life, so it's a little rough for you to visit your displeasure on me.

column2: He smiled tolerantly as I spoke.
column3: He smiled tolerantly as I spoke.

column2: I knew—and he knew that I did—that no ill feeling against my grandfather lay back of his interest in my affairs.
column3: I knew—and he knew that I did—that no ill feeling against my grandfather lay back of his interest in my affairs.

column2: “You’re not quite the man your grandfather was, Mr. Glenarm.
column3:
You're not quite the man your grandfather was, mr Glenarm.	true	421.55	424.9	26.397552
4595_45204_000036_000001	You’ll excuse my bluntness, but I take it that you’re a frank man.	You'll excuse my bluntness, but I take it that you're a frank man.	true	424.97	428.65	26.897655
4595_45204_000036_000002	He was a very keen person, and, I’m afraid,”—he chuckled with evident satisfaction to himself,—”I’m really afraid, Mr. Glenarm, that you’re not!”	He was a very keen person, and, I'm afraid,—he chuckled with evident satisfaction to himself,—"I'm really afraid, mr Glenarm, that you're not!"

column2: “There you have it, Morgan!
column3:
There you have it, Morgan!	true	438.17	439.39	23.17532
4595_45204_000037_000001	I fully agree with you! I’m as dull as an oyster; that’s the reason I’ve called on you for enlightenment.	I fully agree with you! I'm as dull as an oyster; that's the reason I've called on you for enlightenment.	true	439.52	444.88	22.329638
4595_45204_000037_000002	Consider that I’m here under a flag of truce, and let’s see if we can’t come to an agreement.”	Consider that I'm here under a flag of truce, and let's see if we can't come to an agreement.

column2: “It’s too late, Mr. Glenarm; too late.
column3:
It's too late, mr Glenarm; too late.	false	449.73	453.1	19.96745
4595_45204_000038_000001	There was a time when we might have done some business; but that’s past now.	There was a time when we might have done some business; but that's past now.	true	453.32	457.03	23.730825
4595_45204_000038_000002	You seem like a pretty decent fellow, too, and I’m sorry I didn’t see you sooner; but better luck next time.”	You seem like a pretty decent fellow, too, and I'm sorry I didn't see you sooner; but better luck next time.

column2: He stroked his yellow beard reflectively and shook his head a little sadly.
column3: He stroked his yellow beard reflectively and shook his head a little sadly.

column2: He was not a bad-looking fellow; and he expressed himself well enough with a broad western accent.
column3: He was not a bad looking fellow; and he expressed himself well enough with a broad western accent.

column2: “Well,”
column3: Well,

column2: I said, seeing that I should only make myself ridiculous by trying to learn anything from him, “I hope our little spats through windows and on walls won’t interfere with our pleasant social relations.
column3: I said, seeing that I should only make myself ridiculous by trying to learn anything from him, "I hope our little spats through windows and on walls won't interfere with our pleasant social relations.

column2: And I don’t hesitate to tell you,”—I was exerting myself to keep down my anger,—”that if I catch you on my grounds again I’ll fill you with lead and sink you in the lake.”
column3: And I don't hesitate to tell you,"—I was exerting myself to keep down my anger,—"that if I catch you on my grounds again I'll fill you with lead and sink you in the lake."

column2: “Thank you, sir,” he said, with so perfect an imitation of Bates’ voice and manner that I smiled in spite of myself.
column3: Thank you, sir, he said, with so perfect an imitation of Bates' voice and manner that I smiled in spite of myself.

column2: “And now, if you’ll promise not to fire into my back I’ll wish you good day.
column3:
And now, if you'll promise not to fire into my back I'll wish you good day.	true	503.45	507.93	20
4595_45204_000042_000001	Otherwise—”	Otherwise—

column2: He snatched off his hat and bowed profoundly.
column3: He snatched off his hat and bowed profoundly.

column2: “It’ll suit me much better to continue handling the case on your grounds,” he said, as though he referred to a business matter.
column3: It'll suit me much better to continue handling the case on your grounds, he said, as though he referred to a business matter.

column2: “Killing a man on your own property requires some explaining—you may have noticed it?”
column3: Killing a man on your own property requires some explaining—you may have noticed it?

column2: “Yes; I commit most of my murders away from home,”
column3: Yes; I commit most of my murders away from home,

column2: I said.
column3: I said.

column2: “I formed the habit early in life.
column3:
I formed the habit early in life.	true	528.71	530.65	22.235811
4595_45204_000044_000003	Good day, Morgan.”	Good day, Morgan.

column2: As I turned away he closed his door with a slam,—a delicate way of assuring me that he was acting in good faith, and not preparing to puncture my back with a rifle-ball.
column3: As I turned away he closed his door with a slam,—a delicate way of assuring me that he was acting in good faith, and not preparing to puncture my back with a rifle ball.

column2: I regained the lake-shore, feeling no great discouragement over the lean results of my interview, but rather a fresh zest for the game, whatever the game might be.
column3: I regained the lake shore, feeling no great discouragement over the lean results of my interview, but rather a fresh zest for the game, whatever the game might be.

column2: Morgan was not an enemy to trifle with; he was, on the other hand, a clever and daring foe; and the promptness with which he began war on me the night of my arrival at Glenarm House, indicated that there was method in his hostility.
column3: Morgan was not an enemy to trifle with; he was, on the other hand, a clever and daring foe; and the promptness with which he began war on me the night of my arrival at Glenarm House, indicated that there was method in his hostility.

column2: The sun was going his ruddy way beyond St. Agatha’s as I drove my canoe into a little cove near which the girl in the tam-o’-shanter had disappeared the day before. The shore was high here and at the crest was a long curved bench of stone reached by half a dozen steps, from which one might enjoy a wide view of the country, both across the lake and directly inland.
column3: The sun was going his ruddy way beyond saint Agatha's as I drove my canoe into a little cove near which the girl in the tam o'-shanter had disappeared the day before. The shore was high here and at the crest was a long curved bench of stone reached by half a dozen steps, from which one might enjoy a wide view of the country, both across the lake and directly inland.

column2: The bench was a pretty bit of work, boldly reminiscential of Alma Tadema, and as clearly the creation of John Marshall Glenarm as though his name had been carved upon it.
column3: The bench was a pretty bit of work, boldly reminiscential of Alma Tadema, and as clearly the creation of john Marshall Glenarm as though his name had been carved upon it.

column2: It was assuredly a spot for a pipe and a mood, and as the shadows crept through the wood before me and the water, stirred by the rising wind, began to beat below, I invoked the one and yielded to the other.
column3: It was assuredly a spot for a pipe and a mood, and as the shadows crept through the wood before me and the water, stirred by the rising wind, began to beat below, I invoked the one and yielded to the other.

column2: Something in the withered grass at my feet caught my eye. I bent and picked up a string of gold beads, dropped there, no doubt, by some girl from the school or a careless member of the summer colony.
column3: Something in the withered grass at my feet caught my eye. I bent and picked up a string of gold beads, dropped there, no doubt, by some girl from the school or a careless member of the summer colony.

column2: I counted the separate beads—they were round and there were fifty of them.
column3: I counted the separate beads—they were round and there were fifty of them.

column2: The proper length for one turn about a girl’s throat, perhaps; not more than that!
column3: The proper length for one turn about a girl's throat, perhaps; not more than that!

column2: I lifted my eyes and looked off toward St. Agatha’s.
column3: I lifted my eyes and looked off toward saint Agatha's.

column2: “Child of the red tam-o’-shanter, I’m very sorry I was rude to you yesterday, for I liked your steady stroke with the paddle; and I admired, even more, the way you spurned me when you saw that among all the cads in the world I am number one in Class A. And these golden bubbles (O girl of the red tam-o’-shanter!), if they are not yours you shall help me find the owner, for we are neighbors, you and I, and there must be peace between our houses.”
column3: Child of the red tam o'-shanter, I'm very sorry I was rude to you yesterday, for I liked your steady stroke with the paddle; and I admired, even more, the way you spurned me when you saw that among all the cads in the world I am number one in Class a And these golden bubbles (O girl of the red tam o'-shanter!), if they are not yours you shall help me find the owner, for we are neighbors, you and I, and there must be peace between our houses.

column2: With this foolishness I rose, thrust the beads into my pocket, and paddled home in the waning glory of the sunset.
column3: With this foolishness I rose, thrust the beads into my pocket, and paddled home in the waning glory of the sunset.

column2: That night, as I was going quite late to bed, bearing a candle to light me through the dark hall to my room, I heard a curious sound, as of some one walking stealthily through the house.
column3: That night, as I was going quite late to bed, bearing a candle to light me through the dark hall to my room, I heard a curious sound, as of some one walking stealthily through the house.

column2: At first I thought Bates was still abroad, but I waited, listening for several minutes, without being able to mark the exact direction of the sound or to identify it with him.
column3: At first I thought Bates was still abroad, but I waited, listening for several minutes, without being able to mark the exact direction of the sound or to identify it with him.

column2: I went on to the door of my room, and still a muffled step seemed to follow me,—first it had come from below, then it was much like some one going up stairs,—but where?
column3: I went on to the door of my room, and still a muffled step seemed to follow me,—first it had come from below, then it was much like some one going up stairs,—but where?

column2: In my own room I still heard steps, light, slow, but distinct.
column3: In my own room I still heard steps, light, slow, but distinct.

column2: Again there was a stumble and a hurried recovery,—ghosts, I reflected, do not fall down stairs!
column3: Again there was a stumble and a hurried recovery,—ghosts, I reflected, do not fall down stairs!

column2: The sound died away, seemingly in some remote part of the house, and though I prowled about for an hour it did not recur that night.
column3: The sound died away, seemingly in some remote part of the house, and though I prowled about for an hour it did not recur that night.
